newsitem.title: USA: Telecommunication stocks tick up on court move.
newsitem.headline: Telecommunication stocks tick up on court move.

text.p: U.S. telecommunication shares were generally firmer against a slightly weaker broad market on Tuesday after news the U.S. Supreme Court declined to lift a suspension of a Federal Communications Commission order.
Analysts said that it helped to slightly ease the uncertainty across the industry, but worries about competition remain, reflected in the sector's 1996 underperformance.

"Most fund managers are not bogging themselves down in the legal details of stays, suspensions and so on, but have moved to the sidelines because of broad industry uncertainties," said Bill Deatherage of Bear Stearns.

AT&T Corp, already up 1-3/8 on Monday, added a further 5/8 to 37-3/4 by 1030 EDT/1530 GMT. Other long distance companies added around one percent, while regional Bells were half a percent to one percent stronger.

"(For AT&T) I would discount the Supreme Court ruling," said Barry Sine of SBC Warburg. He said the rise was probably substantial bargain hunting by investors looking for an earnings improvement in the Spring.
But Deatherage said it was not a change of sentiment in AT&T, more of a reaction from oversold levels.
"I call that a dead cat bounce," he said.
The Supreme Court on Tuesday declined a request by federal regulators to reactivate rules meant to pry open U.S. local phone monopolies to competition.

The action means that, for now, deregulation of the $100 billion local phone market will depend on rulings by state regulators in the 50 states -- instead of uniform rules set by the FCC. -- Nick Louth, New York Newsroom 212 859 1610
